_link.title: I can use density data to predict whether a substance will float or sink in water

toLevel2.question: What is the density of water that we compare other substances to?

options.text: 1.0 g/cm³
0.5 g/cm³
options.explanation: 0.5 g/cm³ is not the density of water; water has a density of 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: 2.0 g/cm³
options.explanation: 2.0 g/cm³ is twice the density of water; water's density is 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: 10 g/cm³
options.explanation: 10 g/cm³ is much higher than water's density of 1.0 g/cm³.

toLevel2.question: A substance has a density of 0.7 g/cm³. What will it do when placed in water?

options.text: Float on water
Sink in water
options.explanation: A substance sinks only if its density is greater than 1.0 g/cm³; 0.7 g/cm³ is less.

options.text: Dissolve in water
options.explanation: Density determines floating or sinking, not whether a substance dissolves.

options.text: Stay suspended in the middle
options.explanation: A substance stays suspended only if its density equals that of water, not if it is lower.

toLevel2.question: Which of these densities would cause a substance to sink in water?

options.text: 2.7 g/cm³
0.9 g/cm³
options.explanation: 0.9 g/cm³ is less than water's density so the substance would float.

options.text: 0.5 g/cm³
options.explanation: 0.5 g/cm³ is less than water's density so the substance would float.

options.text: 0.3 g/cm³
options.explanation: 0.3 g/cm³ is much less than water's density so the substance would float.

toLevel2.question: Lithium has a density of 0.53 g/cm³. What happens when lithium is placed in water?

options.text: It floats on the water
It sinks to the bottom
options.explanation: Lithium's density is less than 1.0 g/cm³ so it floats, not sinks.

options.text: It stays in the middle of the water
options.explanation: Lithium's density is not equal to water's, so it does not stay suspended.

options.text: It cannot be placed in water
options.explanation: Lithium can be placed in water; it floats because its density is less than water's.

toLevel2.question: A substance floats on water. What must be true about its density?

options.text: Its density is less than 1.0 g/cm³
Its density is greater than 1.0 g/cm³
options.explanation: A substance with density greater than water sinks, not floats.

options.text: Its density is exactly 1.0 g/cm³
options.explanation: A substance with the same density as water would be neutrally buoyant, not floating on the surface.

options.text: Its density cannot be determined
options.explanation: If a substance floats, we can determine that its density is less than water's.

toLevel2.template: A substance will {{blank:1}} on water if its density is less than {{blank:2}} g/cm³.
If a substance has a density {{blank:1}} than water, it will sink to the {{blank:2}}.
The density of water is {{blank:1}} g/cm³. Substances with lower density will {{blank:2}}.

toLevel2.statement: A substance with a density of 0.8 g/cm³ will float on water.
toLevel2.explanation: 0.8 g/cm³ is less than water's density of 1.0 g/cm³, so the substance floats.

toLevel2.statement: A substance with a density of 3.5 g/cm³ will float on water.
toLevel2.explanation: 3.5 g/cm³ is greater than water's density of 1.0 g/cm³, so the substance sinks.

toLevel3.question: Iron has a density of 7.87 g/cm³ and aluminium has a density of 2.70 g/cm³. Which statement is correct?

options.text: Both metals sink in water because both have densities greater than 1.0 g/cm³
Aluminium floats because it is lighter than iron
options.explanation: Although aluminium is less dense than iron, its density is still greater than water's 1.0 g/cm³, so it sinks.

options.text: Iron sinks but aluminium floats because aluminium is a light metal
options.explanation: Being a 'light metal' does not mean it floats; aluminium's density of 2.70 g/cm³ is still above 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: Neither metal can be placed in water safely
options.explanation: Both metals can be placed in water; whether they float or sink depends on density, not safety.

toLevel3.question: Sodium has a density of 0.97 g/cm³. Why does sodium float when placed in water?

options.text: Because its density is less than the density of water (1.0 g/cm³)
Because it reacts with water and produces gas
options.explanation: While sodium does react with water, its floating is due to its low density, not the reaction.

options.text: Because it is a very small piece of metal
options.explanation: Size does not determine whether a substance floats; density does.

options.text: Because all metals float on water
options.explanation: Most metals have densities greater than water and sink; only a few like sodium float.

toLevel3.question: An unknown substance has a density of 1.0 g/cm³. What would you expect to observe?

options.text: The substance would be neutrally buoyant, neither floating nor sinking
The substance would float on the surface
options.explanation: Floating requires a density less than water; equal density means neutral buoyancy.

options.text: The substance would sink rapidly to the bottom
options.explanation: Sinking requires a density greater than water; equal density means neutral buoyancy.

options.text: The substance would dissolve immediately
options.explanation: Density equal to water does not cause dissolving; solubility is a different property.

toLevel3.question: Potassium (density 0.86 g/cm³) and calcium (density 1.55 g/cm³) are both Group 1 and Group 2 metals. Which correctly predicts their behaviour in water?

options.text: Potassium floats and calcium sinks
Both metals float on water
options.explanation: Calcium's density of 1.55 g/cm³ is greater than 1.0 g/cm³, so calcium sinks.

options.text: Both metals sink in water
options.explanation: Potassium's density of 0.86 g/cm³ is less than 1.0 g/cm³, so it floats.

options.text: Calcium floats and potassium sinks
options.explanation: This is reversed; potassium has the lower density and floats.

toLevel3.question: Why do most metals sink in water?

options.text: Because most metals have densities much greater than 1.0 g/cm³
Because metals are heavy objects and heavy things always sink
options.explanation: It is density, not total weight, that determines sinking; a large block of wood is heavy but floats.

options.text: Because metals react with water
options.explanation: Reactivity with water does not determine floating or sinking; density does.

options.text: Because metals are shiny and smooth
options.explanation: Surface appearance has no effect on whether a substance floats or sinks.

toLevel3.question: Oil has a density of approximately 0.9 g/cm³. Why does oil float on water?

options.text: Because oil's density is less than water's density of 1.0 g/cm³
Because oil does not mix with water
options.explanation: Immiscibility explains why oil and water separate, but floating specifically is due to oil's lower density.

options.text: Because oil is a liquid and liquids always float on water
options.explanation: Mercury is a liquid with density 13.5 g/cm³ and it sinks; floating depends on density.

options.text: Because oil is lighter in colour than water
options.explanation: Colour has no relationship to density or floating behaviour.

toLevel3.template: To predict if a substance floats or sinks, compare its {{blank:1}} to the density of {{blank:2}}.
Lithium, sodium, and potassium all {{blank:1}} on water because their densities are {{blank:2}} than 1.0 g/cm³.
A substance is neutrally buoyant when its density is {{blank:1}} to the density of the {{blank:2}} it is placed in.

toLevel3.statement: A large steel ship floats because the overall density of the ship (including air inside) is less than the density of water.
toLevel3.explanation: Ships are designed so their overall density (steel plus air-filled space) is less than water, allowing them to float.

toLevel4.question: A student has four substances with the following densities: A = 0.6 g/cm³, B = 1.2 g/cm³, C = 0.9 g/cm³, D = 2.5 g/cm³. How many of these substances will float on water?

options.text: 2 (substances A and C)
1 (only substance A)
options.explanation: Substance C also has a density less than 1.0 g/cm³, so both A and C float.

options.text: 3 (substances A, B, and C)
options.explanation: Substance B has a density of 1.2 g/cm³ which is greater than water, so B sinks.

options.text: 0 (none of them float)
options.explanation: Substances A and C both have densities below 1.0 g/cm³ and would float.

toLevel4.question: A block of wood has a mass of 150 g and a volume of 200 cm³. Will it float or sink in water?

options.text: Float, because its density is 0.75 g/cm³ which is less than water
Sink, because 150 g is a heavy object
options.explanation: Floating depends on density (mass ÷ volume), not mass alone; 150/200 = 0.75 g/cm³ < 1.0.

options.text: Float, because wood always floats on water
options.explanation: Some types of wood like ebony have density greater than water and sink; you must calculate density.

options.text: Sink, because its volume is larger than its mass
options.explanation: A larger volume relative to mass means lower density, which causes floating, not sinking.

toLevel4.question: A substance has a mass of 500 g and a volume of 200 cm³. What is its density and will it float or sink?

options.text: 2.5 g/cm³; it will sink
2.5 g/cm³; it will float
options.explanation: The density is correct but 2.5 g/cm³ is greater than 1.0 g/cm³, so it sinks.

options.text: 0.4 g/cm³; it will float
options.explanation: Density = mass ÷ volume = 500 ÷ 200 = 2.5, not 0.4 (that would be volume ÷ mass).

options.text: 100,000 g/cm³; it will sink
options.explanation: Density = mass ÷ volume, not mass × volume; 500 ÷ 200 = 2.5 g/cm³.

toLevel4.question: Going down Group 1, the densities of the alkali metals generally increase: Li = 0.53, Na = 0.97, K = 0.86, Rb = 1.53, Cs = 1.93 g/cm³. Which alkali metals float on water?

options.text: Lithium, sodium, and potassium
Only lithium
options.explanation: Sodium (0.97) and potassium (0.86) also have densities below 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: Lithium and sodium only
options.explanation: Potassium has a density of 0.86 g/cm³ which is also less than 1.0, so it floats too.

options.text: All five alkali metals
options.explanation: Rubidium (1.53) and caesium (1.93) have densities above 1.0 g/cm³ and would sink.

toLevel4.question: A student places a cube of unknown metal (mass 27 g, volume 10 cm³) into water. What happens?

options.text: It sinks because its density is 2.7 g/cm³
It floats because 27 g is not very heavy
options.explanation: Density = 27 ÷ 10 = 2.7 g/cm³, which is greater than water; mass alone does not determine floating.

options.text: It floats because it is a small cube
options.explanation: Size does not determine floating; density does, and 2.7 g/cm³ > 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: It stays in the middle of the water
options.explanation: Neutral buoyancy requires a density of exactly 1.0 g/cm³; this substance has 2.7 g/cm³.

toLevel4.question: If you layer three liquids in a beaker — mercury (13.5 g/cm³), water (1.0 g/cm³), and oil (0.9 g/cm³) — what order would they settle from bottom to top?

options.text: Mercury (bottom), water (middle), oil (top)
Oil (bottom), water (middle), mercury (top)
options.explanation: The densest liquid sinks to the bottom; mercury is densest and oil is least dense.

options.text: Water (bottom), oil (middle), mercury (top)
options.explanation: Mercury is much denser than water and sinks to the bottom, not the top.

options.text: They would all mix evenly
options.explanation: These liquids are immiscible or settle by density; the densest layer goes to the bottom.

toLevel4.question: A hollow steel ball floats on water, but a solid steel ball sinks. Why?

options.text: The hollow ball has a lower overall density because it contains air inside
The hollow ball is made of a different type of steel
options.explanation: Both are steel; the difference is the air inside the hollow ball reduces its overall density.

options.text: The hollow ball has less surface area touching the water
options.explanation: Surface area does not determine floating; overall density does.

options.text: The solid ball is heavier so gravity pulls it down more
options.explanation: It is not total weight but density that determines floating; the hollow ball's overall density is below 1.0 g/cm³.

toLevel4.template: To calculate density, use the formula: density = {{blank:1}} ÷ {{blank:2}}.
A substance with a mass of 80 g and a volume of 100 cm³ has a density of {{blank:1}} g/cm³ and will {{blank:2}} on water.
Going down Group 1, density generally {{blank:1}}, but lithium, sodium, and potassium all have densities {{blank:2}} than water.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that a 1 kg block of aluminium (density 2.7 g/cm³) will float because a 1 kg block of wood (density 0.6 g/cm³) floats. What is wrong with this reasoning?

options.text: Floating depends on density, not mass; aluminium's density exceeds water's so it sinks regardless of mass
The student is correct because both have the same mass
options.explanation: Equal mass does not mean equal density; aluminium is denser than water and sinks.

options.text: The aluminium block is smaller so it will sink due to less surface area
options.explanation: Surface area is not the key factor; density determines floating or sinking.

options.text: The wood floats because it is organic, not because of density
options.explanation: Wood floats because its density is less than water's, not because it is organic.

toLevel5.question: Ice has a density of 0.92 g/cm³. A student says 'Ice floats because it is frozen water, and solids always float on their own liquid.' Evaluate this claim.

options.text: The claim is incorrect; ice floats because its density is less than liquid water, but most solids are denser than their liquid form and sink
The claim is correct; all solids float on their liquid form
options.explanation: Most substances are denser as solids than as liquids, so their solid form sinks; water is an exception.

options.text: The claim is correct because ice has air bubbles that make it float
options.explanation: Ice floats due to its crystal structure giving it a lower density, not because of air bubbles.

options.text: The claim is incorrect; ice floats because of surface tension
options.explanation: Surface tension supports very small objects; ice floats because its density is less than liquid water.

toLevel5.question: Mercury has a density of 13.5 g/cm³. Which of these metals would float on mercury?

options.text: Iron (7.87 g/cm³), copper (8.96 g/cm³), and aluminium (2.70 g/cm³) would all float on mercury
Only aluminium would float because it is the lightest metal
options.explanation: All three metals have densities less than mercury's 13.5 g/cm³, so they all float on mercury.

options.text: None of them would float because metals always sink in liquids
options.explanation: Metals float on liquids that are denser than them; mercury is denser than iron, copper, and aluminium.

options.text: Only iron would float because it is magnetic and mercury repels it
options.explanation: Magnetism is irrelevant; floating depends on density, and all three are less dense than mercury.

toLevel5.question: A student measures a substance's mass as 45 g and volume as 50 cm³. They conclude it will 'just barely float.' Is this a valid conclusion?

options.text: Yes, because its density is 0.9 g/cm³ which is close to but still below 1.0 g/cm³, so it floats
No, because 0.9 g/cm³ is too close to 1.0 g/cm³ to predict
options.explanation: Any density less than 1.0 g/cm³ will cause floating; 0.9 is definitively less than 1.0.

options.text: No, because the substance is too heavy at 45 g
options.explanation: Total mass does not determine floating; density (0.9 g/cm³) is what matters.

options.text: Yes, but only if the substance is a solid
options.explanation: The float/sink rule applies to any substance regardless of state; density is the determining factor.

toLevel5.question: A teacher places a sealed bottle half-filled with sand into a tank of water. The bottle floats. A student says the sand must have a density less than water. Evaluate this explanation.

options.text: The explanation is incorrect; the overall density of the bottle (sand + air + plastic) is less than water, even though sand alone is denser
The explanation is correct because the sand is inside the bottle
options.explanation: Sand has a density of about 2.6 g/cm³; the bottle floats because the air inside lowers the overall density.

options.text: The explanation is correct because sand floats on water
options.explanation: Sand grains individually sink in water; the bottle floats due to the air space reducing overall density.

options.text: The explanation is incorrect; the bottle floats due to the plastic being waterproof
options.explanation: Being waterproof keeps water out but floating is due to overall density being less than water.

toLevel5.question: As you go across Period 3 from sodium to argon, the densities of the elements generally increase. How does this relate to their behaviour in water?

options.text: Sodium (0.97 g/cm³) is the only Period 3 element that floats; the rest have densities above 1.0 g/cm³ and sink
All Period 3 elements float because they are in the same period
options.explanation: Being in the same period does not determine floating; most Period 3 elements are denser than water.

options.text: All Period 3 metals sink and all non-metals float
options.explanation: Sodium is a metal that floats; classification as metal or non-metal does not determine floating.

options.text: The trend in density has no connection to floating or sinking behaviour
options.explanation: Density directly determines floating or sinking; the increasing density trend means fewer elements float.

toLevel5.question: A student has two cubes of the same volume. Cube X has a density of 0.85 g/cm³ and Cube Y has a density of 1.15 g/cm³. Both are placed in water. The student claims Cube Y sinks faster than Cube X floats. Is density alone sufficient to determine this?

options.text: No; density tells us which floats and which sinks, but the rate depends on other factors like shape and viscosity
Yes; the higher the density above water, the faster it sinks
options.explanation: While greater density difference contributes to buoyant force, speed also depends on drag, shape, and fluid viscosity.

options.text: Yes; density completely determines how fast objects move in water
options.explanation: Density determines direction (float vs sink) but speed depends on additional factors.

options.text: No; neither cube will move because they are the same volume
options.explanation: Volume being equal does not prevent movement; different densities cause one to float and one to sink.

toLevel5.question: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element at 22.6 g/cm³. If you could make a boat-shaped vessel from osmium, could it float on water?

options.text: Yes, if the vessel is shaped so that the overall density (osmium walls + air inside) is less than 1.0 g/cm³
No, because osmium is too dense to ever float on water
options.explanation: A hollow vessel of any material can float if the overall density including enclosed air is less than water.

options.text: Yes, but only if the osmium is very thin
options.explanation: Thinness alone is not sufficient; the vessel must be shaped to enclose enough air to reduce overall density below 1.0 g/cm³.

options.text: No, because only materials with density below 1.0 g/cm³ can float
options.explanation: Steel ships float despite steel having density ~7.8 g/cm³; overall density of the structure matters.

toLevel5.template: When comparing substances to water, we compare their {{blank:1}} rather than their total {{blank:2}} to predict floating or sinking.
A hollow object can float even if its material is very dense, because the {{blank:1}} inside reduces the {{blank:2}} density below 1.0 g/cm³.
